bow: has anyone not had their husbands in the delivery room by choice the closer we get to the big day the less want him in there absolutely both times could imagine not sharing that experience no my baby daddy is my rock couldnt have done it with out him holding my hand being total worry wart then when she was born and he leaned down and kiss me amd said we did good job she is beautiful makes me cry such wonderful bonding memory to have deleted why would you want your husband there are you fearful he can not handle it need more information had my husband with me the whole time do know how would have handled it without him he kept me calm and during delivery he was right next to me telling me how well was doing it really helped me out more background needed are you seriously contemplating not allowing your husband access to the birth of his child he is your husband not the baby daddy and do think it fair to rob him of such momentous time in his life your life and the beginning of your child life my husband is doof ca get his pants on without written directions but he is an amazing labour partner organised calm sweet and helpful think you need to give your husband more credit deleted could you tell us why you do think you want him there do you think he wo be supportive helpful are you worried he ca handle the blood and ick are you worried that if he sees the baby coming out of your vagina it will affect your future sex life is he deadbeat asshole who you do want in your life do you feel that the delivery room is place for women and the father should be in the waiting room handing out cigars can see so many reasons why you might not want him there some of which went through but ca really address your question properly unless have better idea of which reasons apply why do you want him there am just curious about your reasons he the squeamish type ca even handle anatomical sketches in medical textbooks and ca handle seeing me in pain know he go in to support me if he thought it was his duty but do want to make him feel weak which he often does if in pain and he ca fix it or to have him pass out we ve discussed it few times he very squeamish can only handle blood in combat setting and seeing me in pain kills him feel like ll have enough on my plate without making sure he okay as well and do want him to be upset by the pain blood two things come to mind the first is being in happy unstressed game for whatever state of mind can be really beneficial during childbirth no it wo necessarily make it easy fun and riskless but the reverse being uncomfortable paranoid distracted and strung out can really foul things up so it makes sense to limit the people in the room to people you feel relaxed and safe around and it helps if those people all have job to do so you do have to feel like host or watched pot but and maybe this is just my prejudice speaking think it is really good for fathers to see their kids being born think many of them are quite going to get what you ve gone through how much work is involved how extreme an experience it is unless they get to be there think it can be an intense bonding experience for them both with you and with the baby and remember if he not there he not going to see that baby until its all cleaned up dressed and possibly sleeping the baby may not feel quite as much his at least not at first so you should think long and hard about what kind of experience you think he ought to have what kind of experience you need him to have it might be enough to change your mind after all you need the birth to work for you but you need the postpartum period to work for you too what will make him the best ally maybe ask about birth experiences over at daddit to see what they say edit just reread this and want to make sure not giving the wrong impression do think his birth experience is more important than yours but do think completely different set of important things can happen for dads in the delivery room and it in your family best interest to look at the big picture certainly there are situations where your comfort should override his right to be there are you in one of them he kind of unable to handle blood outside of combat setting he military and seeing me in pain absolutely kills him feel like ll be dealing with enough without constantly checking to see if he okay and that he be happier outside with cigar he kind of unable to handle blood outside of combat setting he military and seeing me in pain absolutely kills him feel like ll be dealing with enough without constantly checking to see if he okay and that he be happier outside with cigar had thought of your second paragraph just worried he wo be able to handle the pain blood well most of the time there no blood until the end as in after there baby to worry about when that time comes he will be ignoring you and paying attention to the baby instead which is as it should be and the pain is not the same as the pain of injury well crowning kind of is but the contractions and pushing are so it does really imo belong in the same mental category though it is certainly more intense than much of the pain you ll experience in your life it more like dry heaves or straining to poop or something like that only for such long period of time and with such intensity that it kind of crosses over into pain maybe if you talk to him about different kinds of pain he ll find way to reconcile himself to it think you should encourage him to be there but give him permission in advance to leave halfway through if he thinks he needs to if you are in labor and you find yourself getting stressed and distracted by the fact that he barely holding it together tht not going to be great for your labor maybe you can find way to make it about you instead of about him you just need to be alone so he wo feel that he let you down see no reason why you guys ca just play this one by ear can almost promise that he will surprise you my husband did he was all up in my business when my son was being born pulled him out well once the doctor got him out safely he let do the rest and cut the cord cried the whole time would never take that experience away from him if you feel he may faint or throw up or whatever have contingency plan have your mom or bff waiting in the wings to slide over if your husband can not handle it but do just disallow him from the experience fair enough have you asked him about what he rather do if he has combat experience he probably remarkably calm under stress and pressure if he wants to be present feel like you would be doing him disservice by excluding him on the other hand if he be happier in the waiting room do what makes both of you happy you re husband is weenie then he does have to look anywhere but at your face if he ca handle the blood he not weenie he handles pain and stress well in combat situations but at home it is an entirely different situation he stated he prefer to wait outside but will be in there if want moral support he stated he rather be outside because *he s* afraid he ll puke or faint but he willing to be in there if want him do want to make him feel unloved or unwanted but feel like having him there would cause ton of stress seeing me in pain especially because terrible at hiding my feelings upsets him terribly if he goes in he ll consider it his duty to stick it out no matter how upsetting it feels honestly think it is shame that he does feel he can be good support for you during this time it was incredibly bonding for my husband to see our son born it not an experience you can ever recapture im not sure what good advice would be here if he himself feels that he does have the stomach to help you that seems little selfish do say that to be unkind but it just seems unfair you will be giving birth in pain but definitely well worth it pain and then you have to have the additional burden of either not having your husband there or demanding his presence and worrying about his response it would be different if he was all gung ho or ya know im scared but really want to be there for our baby and for you and *poof* faints that definitely nobody fault but saying eh do think can deal but *guess* if you reaaaaaallly want me there ll try little upset for you this is the birth of your baby not an appendectomy so guess my advice is this if you want him there he needs to change his mindset none of this guess will do it if you want me to like going out into the battlefield there is no room in his head for error there is no room for failure he needs to be positive and supportive and he needs to say to himself this will be positive experience this will be life altering time for me will be great support for my wife if not if he allows any room for failure in his head he will probably fail can you hire doula have midwife and she has assistants that act like doulas and they were incredibly helpful good luck are you due in december we are having our second in the middle of december congrats he being honest with me he does not think he can deal with it but if want him there he will do his duty and come trust him and know that he knows his limits he does really handle situations where he can not help well he an action sort of guy not moral support the moral support in this marriage am due in december well congrats december is an awesome month hope that you and your husband are pleasantly surprised at his ability to be good support system for you it is really such life altering experience to see your child being born or so hear was little delirious at the time if it what you both want go for it this is *your* child do let society convention anyone pressure you into having your child in way you do want that being said hope you ve chosen someone else to be in the delivery room with you to be your support system having someone to hold your hand and reassure you really helps also be aware that you and or your husband my change your mind on the big day emotions will be flying all over the place ll probably have my mom there though she actually never seen normal birth think the hardest part is we do know whether he ll even be here or not when give birth so planning for it without him feel easier than promising he ll be there and having him be overseas hope he not deploying that happened to my brother though he did manage to get leave in time for my niece arrival my mom would have been my second choice if my husband could have been there he was my rock though he told me later that he felt useless he been deployed four times already so really crossing my fingers that it does happen again well different strokes right everyone is different but before you make the decision for him you should ask him if it what he wants and what you want then do worry about anyone else yeah it was my brother 4th or 5th lose track sadly sending positive thoughts your direction have to say think your description here of the father birth experience is really well written it *is* important my husband did think he want to catch the baby did want to cut the cord wanted the baby cleaned before he held her etc being in that room watching the labor and birth unfold completely changed him he was all up in there and wanted to help guide the baby out held her immediately and handed her to me cut the cord etc it quite the experience devonianage post up there really reminded of me of my husband and my experience and just wanted to comment to you my husband did want to cut the cord wanted the baby cleaned before he held her etc being in that room watching the labor and birth unfold completely changed him he was all up in there and wanted to help guide the baby out held her immediately and handed her to me cut the cord etc it quite the experience my husband is military too and just ca fathom why he would want to be there if he could sure you re aware of all the men who miss their children births due to deployments the fact that he would give that up while men at that very moment are crying and yearning to be with their wives as they birth their children breaks my heart ve asked him and his stance is do not think can do it but if you want me to do it then ll do it he very traditional sort and outside of combat situation he can not abide blood at all ever seeing me in pain also completely destroys him so having those two things together plus the option of no thank you ll wait outside being available and he would rather wait until our son is clean and am not in pain to see him nobody likes to see their partner in pain and like someone else mentioned there not really any blood until the very end do know after going through it just really think it will be detrimental to both of you for him to not be there but though it unconventional suppose it valid choice good luck to you both yeah could imagine giving birth without my husband my heart breaks when hear about women giving birth while their partner is deployed overseas my husband is super squeamish and gets anxiety attacks at the sight of needle but he was champ in the birth think the excitement helped him put that out of his mind he even snuck peak at the head coming out and took picture of the placenta lol well then it sounds like you guys have to do what right for you congrats do you have someone to be in there with you though it seems terrifying to do alone at least from my perspective as someone who is about to have baby in month or so if he ca handle it during labor how will he handle it when his own child is in pain or bleeding profusely it quite literally all in his head and he needs to get over it even if he needs help doing so think of other people getting over phobias ugh would have died aka been really upset some of it does stem from his combat experience and he is in therapy for the ptsd this is actually another fear of mine as he has been deployed times already and it may happen again so rather make plans for him not to be there he has some issues with blood and pain stemming from his combat experience and he is in therapy for the ptsd just do want him going into shutdown while in labor wow what strange responses you are getting on this post think your husband sounds like really good guy and am kind of annoyed about all the negative comments here about him but my husband is ex military so maybe my perspective is different because of experience so here are my thoughts most of the people on this board do apparently understand ptsd ignore all the comments about how week he is or whatever that is just ignorance and annoying it sounds like he wants to be there but he does want to let you down either think he sounds like good guy just wanted to throw in my two cents in the end think he will be there think he wo want to not know what is happening sure he is protective and it will upset him to see you in pain but sure he will also be your strongest advocate and be there for anything you need my husband did want to be there we kept saying he would be in bar nearby but he did want to not be there more he wound up being just wonderful like protective lion you guys will be fine my husband ca deal with blood at all but he was fine in the delivery room he stopped looking below my waist after he saw her crowning and just focused on helping me it really helped that we had great doula who helped him do that without her we both would have had hard time after reading few of the comments this is what think you said that your hubby is dealing with ptsd from his combat experience first of all thank you so much to him for going out there for his country and millions of people that do even know his name secondly ptsd regardless of where it comes from can be an extremely difficult obstacle and really do respect you for being able to think of how he might feel in situation where he is in control and may be trigger for him however the birth of his child is huge deal he is the only person that can support you so intimately and help you bring your baby into your lives and seeing you work through the process and face the pain if you choose to experience the pain may actually end up being somewhat therapeutic in way being such an important part of process that is painful yet so rewarding and positive may be helpful in shining little light on life and pain that have been demonized in regards to his senses during his experiences in combat maybe finding support group class or even birth counselor would help you both prepare for labor and delivery maybe being able to speak to another man who has struggled with ptsd but was able to witness and participate in the birth of their child would be able to address the fears that you both have concerning the event whatever it takes think it would be worth the effort to have him be there to help you and baby through the experience really all three of you are going through this together and it seems like not having your husband there would be negative for all three of you my husband is incredibly squeamish he ca handle blood and guts at all and as far as he concerned girls do poop at first did want him in the delivery room with me he did want to be in there either but he was and do think could have done it without him we both agreed that he had to stay up by my head the whole time the business end was completely off limits because quite honestly wanted to have sex again at some point in my life and did want him too traumatized he also incredibly funny and it turns out that was what needed more than anything else labor is long and extremely boring and he kept me ans the nurses entertained he even handled the gross bits me vomiting inches away from his face while he was trapped between me and wall way better than either of us thought he would you need him there trust me plus the nurses are there to help if it gets to be bit much for him they ll step in and tell him to get some air maybe send him on an errand to get you some water whatever think you both might later regret it if he were there does he *want* to be there your post does really say my husband was much better than expected do think he was really prepared though to see all that was about to happen it was just me and my husband in the room no family was even at the hospital at the time of birth it was easier on me the mom just me and daddy that all baby needed best of luck to you agree with devonianage http www reddit com user devonianage above being in happy unstressed game for whatever state of mind can be really beneficial during childbirth it very personal decision for both of you guess recommend you both learn and discuss lot about what the delivery process and immediate post delivery situation is like your fears are unfounded had severe tearing internal up past the cervix on sides that required the use of big retractors for suturing it took over an hour for repair my husband saw it all and did develop ptsd and ppd and needed therapy newborn is enough to worry about and handle without parent having panic attacks and severe depressive episode if he is already seeing therapist use them to prepare that said my husband was able to address his issues and is fine now he was ultimately glad he was there and would do it again see he has ptsd already and situation like that would entirely shut him down and when he shuts down he gone for *days* he wants to support me but he also afraid of shutting down but he an adult he should be able to control himself and support you too this is his child as much as it yours if he is going to be careless or selfish then consider limiting his time with you otherwise afford him the opportunity to share this experience with you plus men that experience birth are more sympathetic partners my uncle passed out and puked for the birth of both of my cousins they had chair ready and waiting for him he would have had it any other way he coping with ptsd and the ramifications of that make this little different from him being careless or selfish get him comfortable chair and give him leave if gets to be too much he may still surprise you but let him at least see the process in action side comment ptsd is kind of big deal when asking strangers for advice ended up with an emergency ceserean and banned my partner from the operating room he is an iraqi war veteran with severe ptsd and was worried that the gore from surgery would cause flashback
